name: Rooting For Tubers Festival
description: Get ready, Bangalore! Rooting for Tubers is back and better than ever. This year’s festival brings you an exciting mix of food, culture, and nature, all wrapped up in the humble yet powerful tuber. It’s a fun, family-friendly day out, co-curated by Spudnik Farms and culinary creatives, to celebrate the vibrant world of tubers. Come with your friends, family, or even solo, and immerse yourself in a one-of-a-kind experience exploring flavours, traditions, and sustainability!Whether you're a food enthusiast, an eco-conscious eater, or someone looking for a relaxed picnic-style festival, Rooting for Tubers will leave you inspired and hungry for more!What’s in store:15+ Community & Market StallsExplore diverse stalls featuring local farmers, producers, and communities, all sharing unique tuber varieties and other farm-fresh produce. Discover exciting new ways to cook with tubers, support small-scale farmers, and stock up on your favourite finds at the market.  Interact and meet various tuber growing communities from across India!Culinary Stalls & Live CookingWatch chefs in action as they cook up delicious tuber-inspired dishes! Learn from the best as they explore tubers in creative and sustainable ways, showcasing the potential of these crops in modern cooking.Workshops & TalksLearn from experts in hands-on workshops, including fermentation, traditional cooking methods, and nutrition. Engage in conversations around biodiversity, sustainable food systems, and the cultural significance of tubers, while interacting with both culinary professionals and farmers.Art Installation & Tuber DisplayDelve into the artistic side of tubers through a collaborative art installation, featuring a colourful display of various indigenous tuber varieties. Discover the beauty and biodiversity of tubers while learning about the role they play in climate resilience and food security.

name: ALT EFF 2024 x Courtyard Koota
description: Since the dawn of time, storytelling in community has shaped our mindset, our outlook and ultimately, our behavior. With record heat, oscillating droughts & floods, fires, melting glaciers (and ... you know the rest) our current narrative needs some course correcting.All Living Things Environmental Film Festival (ALT EFF) is back for a 5th edition, pan-India cultural event. Join us at Courtyard Koota for a unique evening of cinema, art & community. Watch award-winning global films on regeneration, activism, resilience and hope and engage in conversations with India’s most inspiring change-makers. Let’s restore the narrative of stewardship, together. All are welcome!PROGRAM:27th November, Wednesday6:30 - 6:45 PM : Some Thoughts on the Common Toad6:45 - 7:45 PM : A Flaming Forest7:45 - 8:30 PM: Q & A with A Flaming Forest and Discussion29th November, Friday6:30 - 7:00 PM : Tomorrow, the Burning Heavens7:00 - 8:00 PM : Miles Away 8:00 - 8:45 PM : ALT EFF Voices (With prompts and select curation provided by us, this is an open-mic for audiences to)PROGRAM DETAILS: Some Thoughts on the Common Toad (G. Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023)A cine-collage manifesto inspired by George Orwell’s essay, with Tilda Swinton narrating. The film uses a blend of images and sound to highlight the common toad as a symbol of natural beauty amidst environmental and political decay. It contrasts the elegance of nature with contemporary issues, urging viewers to reconsider their relationship with the environment and appreciate its beauty and significance.A Flaming Forest (Salman Javeed, Satya Ambasta, Vivek Sangwan | India | 48 mins 27 secs | Kannada, English | 2024)Exclusionary conservation practices in the Biligiri Rangaswamy Temple (BRT) Tiger Reserve have displaced Soliga adivasis from the forests they have historically inhabited. The film documents their intimate relationship with the forest, displacement induced loss and resistance against such policies, calling for an alternative vision to conservation.Tomorrow, the Burning Heavens (Max Bloching | Germany | 22 mins 06 secs | German | 2024)This short film explores the 1560s` ‘Little Ice Age’ and its apocalyptic fears, illustrated in hand-coloured woodblock prints. The film juxtaposes these historical anxieties with modern-day artificial winter landscapes in the Alps, created for skiing resorts. By merging past and present, it examines how image-making, technology, and faith interact amidst environmental crises, reflecting on our evolving perceptions of nature and climate change.Miles Away (Megha Acharya | India | 50 mins | Bundeli, Hindi | 2023)The film follows the journey of three women who work at a brick kiln on the outskirts of a city in North India, in the midst of extreme rains and a global pandemic. What unfolds is a story of mobility, debt and the everyday lives of the caste-oppressed women, whose labour is both crucial and too often invisible, in the story of a rapidly urbanising global India.

3:20 PM : Burnt Country3:20 - 4:30 PM : Nenets vs Gas4:30 - 5:00 PM : ALT EFF Voices With prompts and/or select curation provided by us, this is an open-mic for audiences to express themselvesPROGRAM DETAILS:Batsies (Liz Unger | USA | 15 mins 22 secs | English | 2023)Batsies is an experimental short documentary about two wildlife biologists, Sara Weaver and Sarah Fritts, who challenge the stigma surrounding bats. Based in Texas, these quirky, tattooed women tackle cutting-edge bat research, focusing on threats from wind turbines. Despite the crucial role bats play in agriculture, their public image has worsened since COVID-19. The film highlights their unique friendship and dedication to saving these misunderstood creatures.Covered in mud, buried under myths: Red sand boa illegal trade (Shatabdi Charkraborti | India | 13 mins 32 secs | English, Hindi | 2024)Immaculate (Ningjing Wang | China, UK | 15 mins 40 secs | Chinese, English | 2024) In rural China, ecologist Amaël Borzée spends five years listening to the fading calls of Chinese immaculate tree frogs. When filmmaker Ningjing Wang, a lifelong frog enthusiast, joins him, they unite to uncover the secrets of this elusive species. Their journey reveals the shared struggles of the frogs and rural communities. Together, they strive to secure a future for these endangered amphibians and their environment.Requiem for a Whale (Ido Weisman | Israel | 15 mins 27 secs | Hebrew | 2022)On a stormy night in early 2021, a beached whale washes ashore at Nitzanim Beach, Israel. The film documents the whale’s burial and features phone calls between the director and the witnesses: a photographer, a news reporter, and a Bedouin tractor driver. The encounter with the whale’s corpse evokes the witnesses` thoughts about the dialogue between death and life.The Legend of Goldhorn (Lea Vucko | Slovenia | 13 mins 35 secs | No Dialogue | 2022) A heartbroken hunter, driven by grief and madness, ventures into the mountains, and goes against the mythical power of nature. Haunted by visions of his lost love, he is led by a shadowy guide to hunt the mythical Goldhorn, which ultimately leads to his demise. This 13-minute, dialogue-free film, inspired by Slovenian folklore, explores themes of greed and our relationship with nature, enhanced by a traditional Slavic musical score.Crying Glacier (Lutz Stautner, Philipp Becker | Germany, Switzerland | 14 mins 13 secs | English | 2023)The louder the glacier, the stronger the melt. The creaking, cracking and rippling is the voice of impermanence. Sound artist Ludwig Berger shows how important it is to listen to the world that surrounds us. The film follows him on one of his numerous visits to Morteratsch glacier in the Swiss Alps, where he collects fascinating sounds that might disappear forever. Tomorrow, the Burning Heavens (Max Bloching | Germany | 22 mins 06 secs | German | 2024)This short film explores the 1560s` ‘Little Ice Age’ and its apocalyptic fears, illustrated in hand-coloured woodblock prints. The film juxtaposes these historical anxieties with modern-day artificial winter landscapes in the Alps, created for skiing resorts. By merging past and present, it examines how image-making, technology, and faith interact amidst environmental crises, reflecting on our evolving perceptions of nature and climate change.Disha Swarajyachi (Towards Self-Governance) (Virendra Valsangkar | India | 53 mins 20 secs | Marathi | 2023)Disha Swarajyachi (Towards Self-Governance) is a documentary about a tribal village in Gadchiroli, Maharashtra, known for its consensus-based decision-making. As the first village in India to acquire `Forest Rights,` it has achieved social and financial independence through this practice. The film showcases how this model of working together as a family can be implemented by any community willing to unite and collaborate.Once Upon a Time in a Forest (Virpi Suutari | Finland | 1 hr 33 mins | Finnish, English | 2024)A modern fairy tale set in Finland’s enchanting woodlands, where young people thrive in harmony with nature. As they enjoy the forest`s beauty, 22-year-old Ida leads the Forest Movement against threats from industrial exploitation. The film captures Ida`s inspiring battle to protect the forest and its serene beauty, underscoring the critical conflict between conservation and development.Lullaby of waves (Ayon Pratim Saikia | India | 15 mins 20 secs | Assamese | 2023) A 53-year-old woman reflects on 26 years of marriage and motherhood, focusing on her struggles for employment in Assam’s remote Sadiya region, divided by the Brahmaputra River. Viewed as an outsider, she faced challenges to her home and identity. Narrated by her son, the film explores themes of belonging, resilience, and the enduring impact of the river on their lives as they question whether this land is truly home.Moon Without a House (Atanur Nabiyeva | Azerbaijan | 22 mins 03 secs | Azerbaijani | 2023)Moon Without a House (Atanur Nabiyeva) explores the lives of a grandmother and granddaughter named Tazaghul, who live in a remote Azerbaijani mountain hut. Through serene visuals, the film reveals their deep bond and enduring resilience against a backdrop of desolation. The name "Tazaghul," meaning "fresh flowers," contrasts with their rugged surroundings, symbolising hope and love in isolation. The film poignantly captures their vanishing way of life and emotional strength.Gopi (Nishanth Gurumurthy | India | 13 mins 50 secs | Kannada | 2022)Gopi Siddi is a middle-aged storyteller who identifies herself with the Siddi community (African Diaspora in South India). Inspired by the oral form of storytelling, Gopi desires to get her stories self published; however, she must first face her battles with alienation, social standing, and environmental catastrophe.Searching for soppu: Foraging food in Bengaluru (Ridah Zaman | India | 9 mins 20 secs | Kannada, English | 2024)The Climate Baby Dilemma (Victoria Lean | Canada | 44 mins | English | 2022)The Climate Baby Dilemma follows science writer Britt Wray as she explores the emotional decision of having children amid climate change. Over three years, Britt engages with activists, psychologists, and parents, while many Gen-Z and millennials question bringing a child into an unstable world. The film also features climate-conscious parents like Sarain Fox and Severn Suzuki, offering insights on transforming climate anxiety into action, including the choice to forgo parenthood.Kenya`s Desert Alert (David Owino | Kenya | 15 mins 03 secs | English | 2024)Akunthit (Rahul Barman | India | 15 mins 59 secs | Assamese | 2023)Gopal Nag from Chandamari village in Assam, who lost his lower limbs in a 2014 accident, turned to sustainable farming with his mother’s support. His journey from despair to purpose highlights his resilience and determination. Now, Nag advocates for the disabled to see themselves as specially abled and seek independence, promoting empowerment through equality rather than charity.The Giants (Laurence Billiet, Rachael Antony | Australia | 1 hr 30 mins | English | 2023) The Giants portrays the deep connection between trees and humans through the life of Australian environmental hero and the Australian parliament’s first openly gay member, Bob Brown. The film follows Brown`s journey from a passionate advocate to a central figure in green politics, intertwining his story with the life cycle of the ancient trees he protects. This epic and cinematic film highlights Brown’s activism and sparks urgent conversations about forest preservation and environmental rights.ABBA (Fabiana Lupo | Italy | 14 mins 29 secs | Italian | 2023)A gripping short film that follows two astronauts who land on a planet eerily similar to the Earth their ancestors left behind. Their mission to find water evolves into a profound journey of self-discovery and reflection on humanity`s past. Through stunning visuals and deep narrative, the film explores existential themes of identity, history, and redemption.Some Thoughts on the Common Toad (G. Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023)A cine-collage manifesto inspired by George Orwell’s essay, with Tilda Swinton narrating. The film uses a blend of images and sound to highlight the common toad as a symbol of natural beauty amidst environmental and political decay. It contrasts the elegance of nature with contemporary issues, urging viewers to reconsider their relationship with the environment and appreciate its beauty and significance.A Flaming Forest (Salman Javeed, Satya Ambasta, Vivek Sangwan | India | 48 mins 27 secs | Kannada, English | 2024)Exclusionary conservation practices in the Biligiri Rangaswamy Temple (BRT) Tiger Reserve have displaced Soliga adivasis from the forests they have historically inhabited. The film documents their intimate relationship with the forest, displacement induced loss and resistance against such policies, calling for an alternative vision to conservation. Akunthit (Rahul Barman | India | 15 mins 59 secs | Assamese | 2023)Gopal Nag from Chandamari village in Assam, who lost his lower limbs in a 2014 accident, turned to sustainable farming with his mother’s support. His journey from despair to purpose highlights his resilience and determination. Now, Nag advocates for the disabled to see themselves as specially abled and seek independence, promoting empowerment through equality rather than charity.Wild Summon (Karni and Saul | UK | 14 mins 39 secs | English | 2023)Wild Summon, directed by Karni and Saul, is a natural history fantasy that portrays the wild salmon`s life cycle in human form. Narrated by Marianne Faithfull, the film follows the salmon`s epic journey from freshwater birth to oceanic adulthood and back. This BFI short film blends myth and nature, offering a unique perspective on the profound connection between these remarkable creatures and their environment.Seed Stories (Chitrangada Choudhury | India | 42 mins | Kui, Odiya, English | 2024) Seed Stories follows Dr. Debal Deb and his team as they conserve over 1,000 endangered heirloom rice varieties in a village in Odisha’s Eastern Ghats. This region, rich in biodiversity and traditional agricultural knowledge, faces transformation due to the introduction of genetically modified seeds and chemicals. The documentary explores how these changes are reshaping local farming practices, food culture, and ecological attitudes, prompting viewers to reflect on sustainability.Burnt Country (Kirsten Slemint | Australia | 17 mins 45 secs | English | 2024)Burnt Country explores Australia`s ancient fire management practices rooted in 65,000 years of Indigenous knowledge. The film highlights how First Nations people use controlled burns to care for the land, contrasting with modern methods. It advocates blending these traditional practices with contemporary fire management to address Australia`s environmental challenges and emphasises the deep connection between Indigenous communities and the landscape.

By merging past and present, it examines how image-making, technology, and faith interact amidst environmental crises, reflecting on our evolving perceptions of nature and climate change.Disha Swarajyachi (Towards Self-Governance) (Virendra Valsangkar | India | 53 mins 20 secs | Marathi | 2023)Disha Swarajyachi (Towards Self-Governance) is a documentary about a tribal village in Gadchiroli, Maharashtra, known for its consensus-based decision-making. As the first village in India to acquire `Forest Rights,` it has achieved social and financial independence through this practice. The film showcases how this model of working together as a family can be implemented by any community willing to unite and collaborate.Once Upon a Time in a Forest (Virpi Suutari | Finland | 1 hr 33 mins | Finnish, English | 2024)A modern fairy tale set in Finland’s enchanting woodlands, where young people thrive in harmony with nature. As they enjoy the forest`s beauty, 22-year-old Ida leads the Forest Movement against threats from industrial exploitation. The film captures Ida`s inspiring battle to protect the forest and its serene beauty, underscoring the critical conflict between conservation and development.Lullaby of waves (Ayon Pratim Saikia | India | 15 mins 20 secs | Assamese | 2023) A 53-year-old woman reflects on 26 years of marriage and motherhood, focusing on her struggles for employment in Assam’s remote Sadiya region, divided by the Brahmaputra River. Viewed as an outsider, she faced challenges to her home and identity. Narrated by her son, the film explores themes of belonging, resilience, and the enduring impact of the river on their lives as they question whether this land is truly home.Moon Without a House (Atanur Nabiyeva | Azerbaijan | 22 mins 03 secs | Azerbaijani | 2023)Moon Without a House (Atanur Nabiyeva) explores the lives of a grandmother and granddaughter named Tazaghul, who live in a remote Azerbaijani mountain hut. Through serene visuals, the film reveals their deep bond and enduring resilience against a backdrop of desolation. The name "Tazaghul," meaning "fresh flowers," contrasts with their rugged surroundings, symbolising hope and love in isolation. The film poignantly captures their vanishing way of life and emotional strength.Gopi (Nishanth Gurumurthy | India | 13 mins 50 secs | Kannada | 2022)Gopi Siddi is a middle-aged storyteller who identifies herself with the Siddi community (African Diaspora in South India). Inspired by the oral form of storytelling, Gopi desires to get her stories self published; however, she must first face her battles with alienation, social standing, and environmental catastrophe.Searching for soppu: Foraging food in Bengaluru (Ridah Zaman | India | 9 mins 20 secs | Kannada, English | 2024)The Climate Baby Dilemma (Victoria Lean | Canada | 44 mins | English | 2022)The Climate Baby Dilemma follows science writer Britt Wray as she explores the emotional decision of having children amid climate change. Over three years, Britt engages with activists, psychologists, and parents, while many Gen-Z and millennials question bringing a child into an unstable world. The film also features climate-conscious parents like Sarain Fox and Severn Suzuki, offering insights on transforming climate anxiety into action, including the choice to forgo parenthood.Kenya`s Desert Alert (David Owino | Kenya | 15 mins 03 secs | English | 2024)Akunthit (Rahul Barman | India | 15 mins 59 secs | Assamese | 2023)Gopal Nag from Chandamari village in Assam, who lost his lower limbs in a 2014 accident, turned to sustainable farming with his mother’s support. His journey from despair to purpose highlights his resilience and determination. Now, Nag advocates for the disabled to see themselves as specially abled and seek independence, promoting empowerment through equality rather than charity.The Giants (Laurence Billiet, Rachael Antony | Australia | 1 hr 30 mins | English | 2023) The Giants portrays the deep connection between trees and humans through the life of Australian environmental hero and the Australian parliament’s first openly gay member, Bob Brown. The film follows Brown`s journey from a passionate advocate to a central figure in green politics, intertwining his story with the life cycle of the ancient trees he protects. This epic and cinematic film highlights Brown’s activism and sparks urgent conversations about forest preservation and environmental rights.ABBA (Fabiana Lupo | Italy | 14 mins 29 secs | Italian | 2023)A gripping short film that follows two astronauts who land on a planet eerily similar to the Earth their ancestors left behind. Their mission to find water evolves into a profound journey of self-discovery and reflection on humanity`s past. Through stunning visuals and deep narrative, the film explores existential themes of identity, history, and redemption.Some Thoughts on the Common Toad (G. Anthony Svatek | USA | 10 mins 37 secs | English | 2023)A cine-collage manifesto inspired by George Orwell’s essay, with Tilda Swinton narrating. The film uses a blend of images and sound to highlight the common toad as a symbol of natural beauty amidst environmental and political decay. It contrasts the elegance of nature with contemporary issues, urging viewers to reconsider their relationship with the environment and appreciate its beauty and significance.A Flaming Forest (Salman Javeed, Satya Ambasta, Vivek Sangwan | India | 48 mins 27 secs | Kannada, English | 2024)Exclusionary conservation practices in the Biligiri Rangaswamy Temple (BRT) Tiger Reserve have displaced Soliga adivasis from the forests they have historically inhabited. The film documents their intimate relationship with the forest, displacement induced loss and resistance against such policies, calling for an alternative vision to conservation. Akunthit (Rahul Barman | India | 15 mins 59 secs | Assamese | 2023)Gopal Nag from Chandamari village in Assam, who lost his lower limbs in a 2014 accident, turned to sustainable farming with his mother’s support. His journey from despair to purpose highlights his resilience and determination. Now, Nag advocates for the disabled to see themselves as specially abled and seek independence, promoting empowerment through equality rather than charity.Wild Summon (Karni and Saul | UK | 14 mins 39 secs | English | 2023)Wild Summon, directed by Karni and Saul, is a natural history fantasy that portrays the wild salmon`s life cycle in human form. Narrated by Marianne Faithfull, the film follows the salmon`s epic journey from freshwater birth to oceanic adulthood and back. This BFI short film blends myth and nature, offering a unique perspective on the profound connection between these remarkable creatures and their environment.Seed Stories (Chitrangada Choudhury | India | 42 mins | Kui, Odiya, English | 2024) Seed Stories follows Dr. Debal Deb and his team as they conserve over 1,000 endangered heirloom rice varieties in a village in Odisha’s Eastern Ghats. This region, rich in biodiversity and traditional agricultural knowledge, faces transformation due to the introduction of genetically modified seeds and chemicals. The documentary explores how these changes are reshaping local farming practices, food culture, and ecological attitudes, prompting viewers to reflect on sustainability.Burnt Country (Kirsten Slemint | Australia | 17 mins 45 secs | English | 2024)Burnt Country explores Australia`s ancient fire management practices rooted in 65,000 years of Indigenous knowledge. The film highlights how First Nations people use controlled burns to care for the land, contrasting with modern methods. It advocates blending these traditional practices with contemporary fire management to address Australia`s environmental challenges and emphasises the deep connection between Indigenous communities and the landscape.

name: In the footsteps of the Tiger of Mysore.
description: Discover the history of Bangalore fort, its tales of glory & treachery over the past five centuries with us.The walk begins with a vegetarian breakfast. After that we take our guests to explore the remnants of Tipu's summer palace, the Bangalore fort & the armory.During the course of the walk learn how Anglo-French wars in Europe & North America had their impact in Southern India too.The guests get to learn more about Tipu's weapons on mass destruction of the 18th century & how they influenced the US national anthem & how one small Southern Indian kingdom was a thorn in the East India Company's rule.

name: Malleswara Darshan heritage walk.
description: This is our walk in one of the oldest suburbs of the "old Bangalore". Join us on a 'darshan' of the many temples and other religious institutes that dot this area as we narrate to you its origins and about the celebrities/personalities who called it their 'home'. Also on this walk learn more about the Maratha connection to this neighborhood as well as how a philanthropist not only helped renovate the Kadu Malleswara temple but also helped create an entire lake in the days gone by.See how Kadu Malleswara turned into a "Mall-e-swarm" and is fast losing not only it's heritage structures but also its local culture. In between all the bytes of history we take bites from an iconic eatery in the this area.So join us on this walk next and get to know Malleswaram in a completely new light.

name: Introduction to Tai Chi with Meera
description: Are you someone who believes in exploring meditation in daily life through movement? Tai Chi is an ancient Chinese martial art and mind-body practice known for its slow, flowing movements, which promotes relaxation, balance, and inner peace. Rooted in principles of mindfulness and energy flow, it combines gentle physical movements with relaxed breathing and focused awareness, making it both a form of physical exercise and moving meditation.Join Meera Krishna who has been learning and practicing Tai Chi for the last 17 years. She has facilitated and taught the art for 8 years. Meera Krishna believes her life's calling is to facilitate health and conscious living through Tai Chi ( movement meditation) and Zen art as tools to be healthy, to connect with one's body, understand the mind, explore one's daily life, freeing one's spirit and reclaiming one's natural joyful state of well-being in sync with nature.Few of the many benefits of this workshop includes : Exploring movements to feel energetic, experiencing body awareness & relaxation and a renewed outlook on exploring well-being and healthy living.Kindly ensure to have breakfast 2.5 hours prior to the session and wear loose comfortable cotton clothes, not tight fit.

name: OTJF Listening Sessions: Kraftwerk - The Man Machine - Bengaluru
description: Join us at the library at Goethe Institut/Max Mueller Bhavan, Indiranagar as we journey through one of the most groundbreaking albums of all time—The Man-Machine by Kraftwerk. Hosted by On The Jungle Floor, this event invites you to explore the sleek, futuristic sounds that helped define electronic music and continue to shape modern soundscapes. On the 10th of November, from 4 PM onwards, immerse yourself in the world of the German Electronic Quartet, Kraftwerk, through their 1978 release, The Man Machine. From the mechanical pulse of "The Robots" to the sprawling industrial beauty of "Metropolis" and the hypnotic rhythms of "The Model," we'll spin The Man-Machine in its entirety on vinyl, capturing the fusion of man and machine that made this album a cornerstone of electronic music.Joining us as co-host is illustrator and musician, Sachin Bhatt. Specializing in album art and visual creatives, Sachin has made a significant impact locally and internationally, having worked with artists like Hiatus Kaiyote, Moonchild, The F16s, Kiefer and more.Whether you're an electronic music aficionado or you’re new to Kraftwerk, you’re sure to enjoy this evening of beats, exploration, and deep listening.

name: Screening: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012) | Movie Under the Stars
description: Join us for an open-air screening of The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012), with a three-course dinner and popcorn.*Wines and other beverages will be available for purchase at the venue.About the movieThe Perks of Being a Wallflower follows the story of Charlie, an introverted high school freshman who struggles with mental health issues and traumatic memories from his past. As he begins his first year of high school, he feels isolated and lost until he befriends two charismatic seniors, Sam and her stepbrother Patrick. With their help, Charlie begins to open up, discovering friendship, love, and acceptance.Set in the early 1990s, the film delves into themes of mental health, trauma, and the impact of relationships, capturing the highs and lows of teenage life. Through the course of the story, Charlie learns to embrace his experiences and his unique perspective, ultimately finding his voice. Based on Stephen Chbosky’s bestselling novel, the story is a powerful exploration of self-discovery and resilience.3-Course Dinner MenuCourse 1Nachos with bean chili & cheese dipCourse 2Macaroni & cheese served with potatoes wedges & garlic bread (Veg.)Baked Ziti, pasta baked with chicken, marinara sauce & cheese, Served with potatoes wedges & garlic bread (Non-Veg.)Course 3Devil food cake with red wine & cherries______Terms and ConditionsThe management is not responsible for any injury or damage that may occur during the event.No liability or claims arising from the consumption or intake of any food or drink will be entertained by the management.Parking near the event premises is at the risk of the vehicle owner.Valet service is available at a charge of Rs. 200 per vehicle.Photographs and videos of ticket holders may be uploaded to social media. name: Cultivating Wealth Wellness: A Workshop for Lifelong Prosperity
description: Picture your finances as a well-cultivated ecosystem, where each element—income, savings, investments, and community—works together to support balance and resilience. In this interactive workshop, we’ll build on the strengths you already have, focusing on strategies that align with your priorities for long-term stability and a meaningful legacy. Led by financial expert Anu Seth, this session brings practical insights, guided reflections, and tools to help you nurture your financial ecosystem in ways that grow with you.What Makes This Workshop SpecialThis experience goes beyond traditional planning. Together, we’ll reimagine financial wellness as an adaptable, living ecosystem—one that supports your evolving goals and ensures lasting security for you and those you care about. You’ll get practical insights, relatable examples, and a creative approach to enhance your financial journey, without being bogged down in jargon or rigid plans.Workshop Highlights🌞 Fresh Perspectives: Step back and view your financial landscape holistically, discovering how each part of your ecosystem contributes to its strength and stability.🌱 Mapping Your Financial Ecosystem: Identify and map key elements in your financial life, exploring how these parts work together to provide support now and in the future.💧 Guidance from Anu Seth: Gain accessible, practical insights to deepen your existing financial habits, adapting them to meet both current and future needs.🌿 Tailored Takeaways: Define actionable steps to strengthen your financial ecosystem, backed by resources that will continue to support your journey well into the future.Why You Should AttendIf you’re looking to enhance your approach to financial wellness, this workshop offers a unique opportunity to build on your knowledge, refine your strategies, and shape a legacy that reflects your values. Walk away with insights and tools tailored for a more resilient, balanced financial future.
